RESOLVED_ENTITIES.the interior: camper compartment of Maria De Jesus Garcia's vehicle

AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.United States: country where the legal case is taking place, with a diverse population including individuals of Hispanic descent
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Moore, Texas: location where the incident occurred, approximately 115 miles from the United States-Mexican border, and where border patrol agents had recently apprehended a number of illegal alien smugglers
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Interstate Highway 35: common smuggling route with known alien smuggling activity, subject to roving border patrol stops
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Mexican border: geographical reference point, approximately 115 miles from Moore, Texas, relevant for roving border patrol stops
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.United States-Mexican border: geographical reference point relevant for determining distance and context of illegal alien traffic
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Laredo, Texas: location through which Interstate 35 passes, one of the towns before reaching Moore, Texas
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Brignoni-Ponce standard: a standard for reasonably warranting suspicion in border patrol stops, considering articulable facts such as proximity to the border, unusual behavior of occupants, and other relevant factors
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.5th Circuit Court of Appeals: US Court of Appeals circuit reviewing the case regarding roving border patrols and the Brignoni-Ponce standard
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Maria De Jesus Garcia's vehicle: vehicle searched for undocumented aliens, subject of a court case, and used by Maria De Jesus Garcia during the incident
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.camper compartment of Maria De Jesus Gar: area where occupants were observed scrambling to hide from the border patrol agents' flashlight, potentially in response to the light or to conceal themselves, with five or six people moving and slouching low to get out of the light trying to hide, and where men made an effort to conceal themselves by getting lower than the windows
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.jury in Maria De Jesus Garcia's trial: jury that received a modified Allen charge during deliberations, heeded the charge's admonition to reexamine their views, and deliberated for approximately three hours after receiving the charge
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.district court in Maria De Jesus Garcia': court that handled Maria De Jesus Garcia's trial, made decisions on evidence suppression, and allowed presentation of evidence pertinent to the suppression motion
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Texas: location where the pickup truck was stopped, approximately 115 miles north of the United States-Mexican border
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Mexico: country of origin for illegal migrants
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.U.S.-Mexico border: reference point for determining distance and relevant to the context of illegal alien traffic
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.back seat of Maria De Jesus Garcia's veh: location where five or six men were found attempting to conceal themselves
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.seat in Maria De Jesus Garcia's vehicle: general location where passenger behavior was observed
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Interstate 35: a highway where Maria De Jesus Garcia's vehicle was traveling at an unusual slow speed late at night, known for being a common smuggling route with alien smuggling history and obvious overloading of vehicles
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Cotulla, Texas: location of the border patrol station where agents Stanley Pruszenski and Alfred Baron served
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.area covered by the Cotulla, Texas stati: region served by border patrol agents with a history of illegal alien traffic
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.location of the instant stop: place where Maria De Jesus Garcia's vehicle was stopped by border patrol agents, based on recent apprehensions of illegal alien smugglers in the area and suspicious behavior of the occupants
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Maria De Jesus Garcia's trial: trial where a modified Allen charge was given to the jury and the case must be decided with no indication that it can be better tried or presented at some other time
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.northbound lanes of Interstate Highway 3: portion of the highway where the incident occurred, known for being a common smuggling route with alien smuggling history
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.pickup truck camper: vehicle searched by border patrol agents due to suspicious behavior, frequently used for transporting illegal aliens and having an unusually heavy and overloaded appearance with fogged-over windows indicating breathing cargo
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.pickup truck: vehicle type involved in the incident, appeared heavily loaded with fogged-over windows and exhibited unusual behavior, including occupants attempting to conceal themselves when a flashlight was shined inside
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.truck cab: front part of the pickup truck where passengers were hiding, observed to have multiple females in the front seat and several men in the back seat attempting to conceal themselves when a flashlight was shined inside
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.back seat of the truck: rear part of the pickup truck where additional passengers were found, including five or six men who attempted to hide when a flashlight was directed at them
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.front seat of Maria De Jesus Garcia's ve: location where three women were observed in the truck cab
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.stop on Interstate Highway 35: place where Maria De Jesus Garcia's vehicle was stopped by border patrol agents, based on recent apprehensions of illegal alien smugglers in the area and suspicious behavior of the occupants
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.highways of the United States: public roads where travelers, including those of Hispanic descent, may be stopped by border patrol agents
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Orona-Sanchez case: a case referenced in the ruling where passenger behavior was deemed insufficient to justify a stop
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Lamas case: a case referenced in the ruling with similar passenger behavior
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Pacheco case: a case referenced in the ruling where passengers 'hunkered down' in the seat
AUXILIARY_DESCRIPTIONS.Pena-Cantu case: a case referenced in the ruling with less suspicious passenger conduct
